comment.body: Hi @vjeko the PR (https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/pull/11827) is still draft because it is waiting on meta to accept another change which will require a slight revisit to this work; but I am endeavouring to clear my RocksDB work-in-progress as best I can :-)

Is it possible to reduce the usage of sync point (both in the core code and in the test)? 

It's likely that we will refactor ErrorHandler to reduce the possibility of new race condition. More sync point will make it harder to refactor.

pull_request.title: Fix for RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError starting with recovery_in_prog_ false
pull_request.body:
# Summary

@cbi42 helped investigation and found a potential scenario where `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` may start with `recovery_in_prog_ ` set as false. (and other booleans like `bg_error_` and `soft_error_no_bg_work_`)

**Thread 1**
- `StartRecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()`): (mutex held) sets `recovery_in_prog_ = true`

**Thread 1's `recovery_thread_`**
- (waits for mutex and acquires it)
- `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` -> `ResumeImpl()` -> `ClearBGError()`: sets `recovery_in_prog_ = false`
- `ClearBGError()` -> `NotifyOnErrorRecoveryEnd()`: releases `mutex`

**Thread 2**
- `StartRecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()`): (mutex held) sets `recovery_in_prog_ = true`
- Waits for Thread 1 (`recovery_thread_`) to finish

**Thread 1's `recovery_thread_`**
- re-lock mutex in `NotifyOnErrorRecoveryEnd()`
- Still inside `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()`: sets `recovery_in_prog_ = false`
- Done

**Thread 2's `recovery_thread_`**
- recovery thread started with `recovery_in_prog_` set as `false` 

# Fix
- Instead of clearing bg error inside `ResumeImpl()` which will be cleared again in `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` and cause scenario above, call `ClearBGError()` only once in `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` after successful `ResumeImpl()`.
- Minor typo and linter fixes in `DBErrorHandlingFSTest`

# Test Plan

- `DBErrorHandlingFSTest::MultipleRecoveryThreads` added to reproduce the scenario. 
- Adding `assert(recovery_in_prog_);` at the start of `ErrorHandler::RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` fails the test without the fix and succeeds with the fix as expected.

- `ClearBGError()` -> `NotifyOnErrorRecoveryEnd()`: releases `mutex`

**Thread 2**
- `StartRecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()`): (mutex held) sets `recovery_in_prog_ = true`
- Waits for Thread 1 (`recovery_thread_`) to finish

- Minor typo and linter fixes in `DBErrorHandlingFSTest`

# Test Plan

issue.title: Make OffpeakTimeInfo available in VersionSet
issue.body:
# Summary

As mentioned in  #11893, we are going to use the offpeak time information to pre-process TTL-based compactions. To do so, we need to access `daily_offpeak_time_utc` in `VersionStorageInfo::ComputeCompactionScore()` where we pick the files to compact. This PR is to make the offpeak time information available at the time of compaction-scoring. We are not changing any compaction scoring logic just yet. Will follow up in a separate PR.

There were two ways to achieve what we want. 
1.  Make `MutableDBOptions` available in `ColumnFamilyData` and `ComputeCompactionScore()` take `MutableDBOptions` along with `ImmutableOptions` and `MutableCFOptions`. 
2. Make `daily_offpeak_time_utc` and `IsNowOffpeak()` available in `VersionStorageInfo`. 

We chose the latter as it involves smaller changes.

This change includes the following
- Introduction of `OffpeakTimeInfo` and `IsNowOffpeak()` has been moved from `MutableDBOptions`
- `OffpeakTimeInfo` added to `VersionSet` and it can be set during construction and by `ChangeOffpeakTimeInfo()`
- During `SetDBOptions()`, if offpeak time info needs to change, it calls `MaybeScheduleFlushOrCompaction()` to re-compute compaction scores and process compactions as needed

# Test Plan
- `DBOptionsTest::OffpeakTimes` changed to include checks for `MaybeScheduleFlushOrCompaction()` calls and `VersionSet`'s OffpeakTimeInfo value change during `SetDBOptions()`.
- `VersionSetTest::OffpeakTimeInfoTest` added to test `ChangeOffpeakTimeInfo()`. `IsNowOffpeak()` tests moved from `DBOptionsTest::OffpeakTimes`

issue.title: Rate limiting stale sst files' deletion during recovery
issue.body: As titled. If SstFileManager is available, deleting stale sst files will be delegated to it so it can be rate limited.

comment.body:
@jowlyzhang 

I'm a bit worried about whether there already exists a test case for stale SST files's deletion **actually** going through rate limiting upon **recovery**.

`DBBasicTest.LastSstFileNotInManifest` did go through your change on delegation but the SstFileManager is not set to rate limiting anything so no rate limiting upon recovery's file deletion.

Surprisingly `db_sst_test.cc` has a few SstFileManager with rate limit configured but it does not go through your DeleteDBFile() change . The rate-limiting shows effect in BG flush/compaction trying to clean up stuff instead of in recovery. BG flush/compaction are paths different enough from recovery.

`TEST_F(BlobDBTest, SstFileManagerRestart)` looks like a close one but it does not go through you DeleteDBFile() change, probably due to BlobDB does not go through the same path for delete files upon recovery?

Because of the above, it's not obvious to me what is the existing UT that actually covers the path this PR is aiming for. Ideally there should be one to help catch unintentional change on recovery path that ends up disabling rate limiting, even though the current PR is not risky.

Are you already aware of such UT? I don't find this UT very obvious so if there is already one, noting that in PR summary will be greatly appreciated :)

edit: If there isn't one, maybe the one db_sst_test.cc is worth modifying.

> It's just changing from using env_->DeleteFile to the commonly used deletion API DeleteDBFile so that rate limiting is exercised if it's available through SstFileManager.

I'm a bit worried about if there is already a test case for stale SST files's deletion **actually** going through rate limiting upon **recovery**. 

`DBBasicTest.LastSstFileNotInManifest` did go through your change on delegation but the SstFileManager is not set to rate limiting anything so no rate limiting upon recovery's file deletion.

Surprisingly db_sst_test.cc has a few SstFileManager with rate limit configured but it does not go through your `DeleteDBFile()` change . The rate-limiting shows effect in BG flush/compaction trying to clean up stuff instead of in recovery. BG flush/compaction are paths different enough from recovery.

Because of the above, it's not obvious to me what is the existing UT that actually covers the path this PR is aiming for. Ideally there should be one to help catch unintentional change on recovery path that ends up disabling rate limiting.

Are you already aware of such UT? I don't find this UT very obvious so if there is already one, noting that in PR summary will be greatly appreciated :) 

If there isn't one, maybe the one db_sst_test.cc is worth modifying.

issue.title: Rate limiting stale sst files' deletion during recovery
issue.body: As titled. If SstFileManager is available, deleting stale sst files will be delegated to it so it can be rate limited.

comment.body:
> @jowlyzhang This seems like a feature worth a unit test - either a new UT or a modified one. Could you add one?

`DBBasicTest.LastSstFileNotInManifest` should cover this code path. It would fail with the deletion logic commented out. (I also need to comment out some other backup deletion logic to make it fail). But I think this change itself is not risky or introducing completely new behavior. It's just changing from using `env_->DeleteFile` to the commonly used deletion API `DeleteDBFile` so that rate limiting is exercised if it's available through SstFileManager.

Good example of when the comment for literal argument is helpful. I'd also rename uri to fs_uri to be clear.

`Env::CreateFromUri(ConfigOptions(), /*env_uri*/ "", fs_uri, &fs_env, &fs_env_guard));`

issue.body:
# Summary

@cbi42 helped investigation and found a potential scenario where `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` may start with `recovery_in_prog_ ` set as false. (and other booleans like `bg_error_` and `soft_error_no_bg_work_`)

**Thread 1**
- `StartRecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()`): (mutex held) sets `recovery_in_prog_ = true`

**Thread 1's `recovery_thread_`**
- (waits for mutex and acquires it)
- `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` -> `ResumeImpl()` -> `ClearBGError()`: sets `recovery_in_prog_ = false`
- `ClearBGError()` -> `NotifyOnErrorRecoveryEnd()`: releases `mutex`

**Thread 2**
- `StartRecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()`): (mutex held) sets `recovery_in_prog_ = true`
- Waits for Thread 1 (`recovery_thread_`) to finish

**Thread 1's `recovery_thread_`**
- re-lock mutex in `NotifyOnErrorRecoveryEnd()`
- Still inside `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()`: sets `recovery_in_prog_ = false`
- Done

**Thread 2's `recovery_thread_`**
- recovery thread started with `recovery_in_prog_` set as `false` 

# Fix
- Instead of clearing bg error inside `ResumeImpl()` which will be cleared again in `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` and cause scenario above, call `ClearBGError()` only once in `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` after successful `ResumeImpl()`.
- Minor typo and linter fixes in `DBErrorHandlingFSTest`

- `DBErrorHandlingFSTest::MultipleRecoveryThreads` added to reproduce the scenario. 
- Adding `assert(recovery_in_prog_);` at the start of `ErrorHandler::RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` fails the test without the fix and succeeds with the fix as expected.

issue.title: Expose OptimisticTransactionDBOptions in C API
issue.body:
### Expected behavior
`OptimisticTransactionDB` will allocate 1M mutexes when opening the db by default. This will consume ~114 MiB memory according to our tests. This can be a waste of memory if most transactions are small. This number can be adjusted by [`OptimisticTransactionDBOptions`](https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/blob/793a786fa3c16a2be782024446bd3f8bb5162875/include/rocksdb/utilities/optimistic_transaction_db.h#L68). 

### Actual behavior
However, `OptimisticTransactionDBOptions` is not exposed in C API, unlike `TransactionDBOptions`:

https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/blob/793a786fa3c16a2be782024446bd3f8bb5162875/include/rocksdb/c.h#L2744-L2753

https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/blob/793a786fa3c16a2be782024446bd3f8bb5162875/include/rocksdb/c.h#L2459-L2470

This issue also makes #11439 to be unusable for other languages.

comment.body: This is a pretty big issue for us as well, as we're unable to modify `OccValidationPolicy`.

issue.title: Slow memory leak with rocksdbjni
issue.body:
Hello,

I'm currently using version 8.5.3 of rocksdbjni and I've encountered a persistent memory leak issue. After researching similar problems, I've identified a few potential causes:

One common issue is failing to properly close the RocksObject from Java, as discussed thoroughly in this GitHub issue (https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/issues/9962). This problem appears to have surfaced in versions >= 7.

I attempted to address this by patching the `AbstractNativeReference` and `AbstractImmutableNativeReference` classes in version 8.5.3 with those from version 6.29.5. However, the memory leak persisted. This led me to believe that the issue may not lie in the object closures. Weirdly though, the issues were completely gone when I downgraded to version 6.29.5

Another possibility pertains to cache-related configurations. If index and filter blocks are not cached within the Block cache, they can lead to memory leaks due to their practically limitless nature. I've already configured my blocks to be cached in the block cache with `strict_capacity = true`, so this doesn't appear to be the root cause.

A third potential issue relates to the use of a different memory allocator. Several similar cases have been reported, as referenced in links like https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/issues/10324, http://smalldatum.blogspot.com/2015/10/myrocks-versus-allocators-glibc.html, and https://blog.cloudflare.com/the-effect-of-switching-to-tcmalloc-on-rocksdb-memory-use/.

I'm uncertain about how to implement this with RocksDBJNI. Is recompiling rocks with a special flag necessary, or is LD_PRELOAD sufficient? I attempted using LD_PRELOAD, but I'm unsure if it had the desired effect, as memory usage continued to increase slowly.

Additionally, I have a few lingering questions:

- If downgrading to version 6.29.5 resolved the issue, could it still be related to a memory allocator problem?
- If the issue lies in improper closure of RocksObjects, wouldn't this have been rectified by patching version 8.5.3 with 6.29.5?
- It seems that memory is not being reclaimed even after closing the rocksdb object. A similar issue is outlined here: https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/issues/10324.


I hope this provides a clearer overview of the situation. Any insights or suggestions would be greatly appreciated. 

Thank you!

comment.body: Is there a way to reproduce this in a localized, longevity benchmark?

issue.title: Fix for RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError starting with recovery_in_prog_ false
issue.body:
# Summary

@cbi42 helped investigation and found a potential scenario where `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` may start with `recovery_in_prog_ ` set as false.

**Thread 1**
- `StartRecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()`): (mutex held) sets `recovery_in_prog_ = true`

**Thread 1's `recovery_thread_`**
- (waits for mutex and acquires it)
- `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` -> `ResumeImpl()` -> `ClearBGError()`: sets `recovery_in_prog_ = false`
- `ClearBGError()` -> `NotifyOnErrorRecoveryEnd()`: releases `mutex`

**Thread 2**
- `StartRecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()`): (mutex held) sets `recovery_in_prog_ = true`
- Waits for Thread 1 (`recovery_thread_`) to finish

**Thread 1's `recovery_thread_`**
- re-lock mutex in `NotifyOnErrorRecoveryEnd()`
- Still inside `RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()`: sets `recovery_in_prog_ = false`
- Done

**Thread 2's `recovery_thread_`**
- recovery thread started with `recovery_in_prog_` set as `false` 

# Fix
- Set `recovery_in_prog_` back to `true` after waiting for the previous recover thread to finish and lock is acquired again.
- Minor typo and linter fixes in `DBErrorHandlingFSTest`

# Test Plan

- `DBErrorHandlingFSTest::MultipleRecoveryThreads` added to reproduce the scenario. 
- Adding `assert(recovery_in_prog_);` at the start of `ErrorHandler::RecoverFromRetryableBGIOError()` fails the test without the fix and succeeds with the fix as expected.

issue.title: CircleCI build-windows-vs2019 failure in Java test
issue.body:
CircleCI build-windows-vs2019 is failing with error-

   193>C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\BuildTools\MSBuild\Microsoft\VC\v160\Microsoft.CppCommon.targets(241,5): error MSB8066: Custom build for 'C:\Users\circleci\project\build\CMakeFiles\6c28c13cc3f40b75e1d32e1c082fca9c\java_compiled_rocksdbjni_classes.rule;C:\Users\circleci\project\build\CMakeFiles\6c28c13cc3f40b75e1d32e1c082fca9c\java_class_filelist.rule;C:\Users\circleci\project\build\CMakeFiles\e3306321aeb3befa7242d5709768a54e\rocksdbjni_classes.jar.rule;C:\Users\circleci\project\build\CMakeFiles\d96c33f612259b7962a934bc8088c9c4\java_compiled_rocksdbjni_test_classes.rule;C:\Users\circleci\project\build\CMakeFiles\d96c33f612259b7962a934bc8088c9c4\java_class_filelist.rule;C:\Users\circleci\project\build\CMakeFiles\e3306321aeb3befa7242d5709768a54e\rocksdbjni_test_classes.jar.rule;C:\Users\circleci\project\build\CMakeFiles\d439f5a941803a37ff03cc9bef842ffc\rocksdbjni_test_classes.rule;C:\Users\circleci\project\java\CMakeLists.txt' exited with code 1. [C:\Users\circleci\project\build\java\rocksdbjni_test_classes.vcxproj]
   193>Done Building Project "C:\Users\circleci\project\build\java\rocksdbjni_test_classes.vcxproj" (default targets) -- FAILED.
   188>Done Building Project "C:\Users\circleci\project\build\java\rocksdbjni_test_classes.vcxproj.metaproj" (default targets) -- FAILED.


CircleCI result-
[https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/facebook/rocksdb/33769/workflows/5c5d05d9-ebf3-4b29-84c0-76818fd5f749/jobs/690144](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/facebook/rocksdb/33769/workflows/5c5d05d9-ebf3-4b29-84c0-76818fd5f749/jobs/690144)

PR that might have introduced this - [#11756](https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/pull/11756?fbclid=IwAR34QLZ3kqOzJ1HGcKzE1MgPPq4v4UeUP11o6aQBPP9N6FKWQTwxBde6PNs)

comment.body:
It seems you're not heading toward the root cuase. The problem is definitely the changes to java/CMakeLists.txt in #11756. More detailed error output:

```
  193>CustomBuild:
         Generating CMakeFiles/rocksdbjni_classes.dir/java_class_filelist
         Creating Java archive rocksdbjni_classes.jar
   194>CustomBuild:
         Creating Java archive rocksdbjni_classes.jar
         java.nio.file.FileAlreadyExistsException: C:\Users\circleci\AppData\Local\Temp\rocksdbjni_classes.jar7913437267980843583.jar -> C:\Users\circleci\project\build\java\rocksdbjni_classes.jar
```

So there's an apparent race in the build where two things are trying to generate the same jar. If we look back here, we see a build with JDK21 without the changes and there's only one "Creating Java archive rocksdbjni_classes.jar": https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/facebook/rocksdb/33579/workflows/10a0fac3-3d74-4e3c-85b8-b41310ffd819/jobs/687565

Even a passing build with the changes attempts to build it twice: https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/facebook/rocksdb/33913/workflows/46fedeaf-4721-4fcc-8662-b5a803c368a3/jobs/693800

issue.title: Drop wal record when sequence is illegal
issue.body:
- Our database is corrupted, causing some sequences of wal record to be invalid (but the `record_checksum` looks fine). 
- When we RecoverLogFiles in WALRecoveryMode::kPointInTimeRecovery, `assert(seq <= kMaxSequenceNumber)` will be failed.
- When it is found that sequence is illegal, can we drop the file  to recover as much data as possible ?  Thx !

comment.body: @ajkr has imported this pull request. If you are a Meta employee, you can view this diff [on Phabricator](https://www.internalfb.com/diff/D50698039).
